lead_paragraph: Carmen Irizarry, 60, was killed by her drug-addicted partner in the Bronx, but her 9-year-old granddaughter, Heaven, escaped, avoiding the grim tally of children killed by the people closest to them.

byline.contributor: Nate Schweber contributed reporting, and Susan C. Beachy and Doris Burke contributed research.
byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr., AL BAKER and ASHLEY SOUTHALL

headline.print_headline: Grandmother’s Killing Lays Bare Dilemma in Child Welfare Work
headline.main: Grandmother’s Killing Lays Bare a Dilemma in Child Welfare Work

snippet: Carmen Irizarry, 60, was killed by her drug-addicted partner in the Bronx, but her 9-year-old granddaughter, Heaven, escaped, avoiding the grim tally of children killed by the people closest to them....
abstract: Murder of Carmen Irizarry in South Bronx by her husband Henry Maldonado, which occurred as Irizarry sought to defend her granddaughter Heaven from Maldonado, offers insight into murders of children by people closest to them; most notorious of such cases often incite outrage because caseworkers miss warning signs of domestic abuse, but Heaven's case was slightly complicated by fact that she had solid guardian in her grandmother (Series: Murder in the 4-0).
